comments.body: Could you add Godoc for this interface and its methods?
done
It seems like this should be `GroupVersionKind`.
Nope, that's implied by where it is added to the system.
could we mark as TODO for future cleanup.
Sorry - I don't understand this comment. What you would like to cleanup with it?
Aren't we planning on changing this post etcd3?

I don't think so. I think the interface should remain as it is here.

What we would like to cleanup is the implementation of DeleteCollection in pkg/registry - but there is already a TODO there.
sgtm

Will review first thing tomorrow morning.

On Tuesday, December 8, 2015, Timothy St. Clair notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In pkg/api/rest/rest.go
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/18290#discussion_r46977051
> :
> 
> > @@ -125,6 +125,13 @@ func (w GracefulDeleteAdapter) Delete(ctx api.Context, name string, options *api
> >     return w.Deleter.Delete(ctx, name)
> >  }
> > 
> > +// CollectionDeleter is an object that can delete a collection
> > +// of RESTful resources.
> > +type CollectionDeleter interface {
> 
> sgtm
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/18290/files#r46977051.
@derekwaynecarr - great thanks!

Typically this is untyped (GetterWithOptions accepts runtime.Object) and we support both the old and the new interface.  However, since List() is effectively standard and we don't have a use case for api.ListOptions varying between callers, I'm ok with making this change as is.

Can you add a TODO on this interface to remove label and field selectors (since they are part of api.ListOptions)?

Sure - I want to remove it from both List and Watch (both here in and in the client).
I will add TODO tomorrow.

@smarterclayton @lavalamp 
BTW - the reason I decided for that API was to make it consistent with DeleteOptions in GracefulDeleter.
That's fine.  Delete and List are more similar than Gets to different subresources will be (proxy, logs, status are all different Get schemas)

I'd argue for ListOptions going to unversioned, like we chatted about earlier.

Also can label & field be moved into listOptions?
I guess that's what Clayton said already. :)
Yes - definitely I was to move label and field into listOptions (here and in client, etc.), but I would like to do it in a separate PR.

Separate PR is fine for me, it's mostly busywork refactor.

We have the constructor for delete options because it's impossible to do
"&0" (take address of constant) in Go.  Case is weaker for other value
types.

On Mon, Oct 26, 2015 at 3:52 PM, Wojciech Tyczynski <
notifications@github.com> wrote:

> In pkg/api/rest/rest.go
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/16273#discussion_r43043374
> :
> 
> > @@ -62,7 +62,7 @@ type Lister interface {
> >     // This object must be a pointer type for use with Codec.DecodeInto([]byte, runtime.Object)
> >     NewList() runtime.Object
> >     // List selects resources in the storage which match to the selector.
> > -   List(ctx api.Context, label labels.Selector, field fields.Selector) (runtime.Object, error)
> > -   List(ctx api.Context, label labels.Selector, field fields.Selector, options *api.ListOptions) (runtime.Object, error)
> 
> Yes - definitely I was to move label and field into listOptions (here and
> in client, etc.), but I would like to do it in a separate PR.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/16273/files#r43043374.

OK - thanks.

@lavalamp - moving ListOptions to unversioned is orthogonal change - I will change that in a separate PR.
I think we'll want to move to unversioned.ListOptions eventually, but this is fine now.
I don't understand from reading this how this is plumbed. How do requests flow through this? what is the relationship between r and the returned Handler?

The handler is invoked.  The handler may delegate structured API responses
(objects or errors) to the responder, or construct its own responses.

Will add more godoc.

On Oct 12, 2015, at 4:27 PM, Daniel Smith notifications@github.com wrote:

In pkg/api/rest/rest.go
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/15442#discussion_r41797576:

>  }
> 
>  // Connecter is a storage object that responds to a connection request
>  type Connecter interface {
> - // Connect returns a ConnectHandler that will handle the request/response for a request
> - Connect(ctx api.Context, id string, options runtime.Object) (ConnectHandler, error)
> - // Connect returns an http.Handler that will handle the request/response for a given API invocation.
> - // The provided responder may be used for common API responses.
> - Connect(ctx api.Context, id string, options runtime.Object, r Responder) (http.Handler, error)

I don't understand from reading this how this is plumbed. How do requests
flow through this? what is the relationship between r and the returned
Handler?

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/15442/files#r41797576.

I guess specifically what I'm confused about is that the handler will get a resp.Body to write to, but it has no way to plumb that response.Body into the Responder-- I'm sure I just don't understand the desired flow of information, though.

The caller of the handler has access to the same body - the responder
contract is "invoke Responder and return", while all other flows may
involve custom output.  The primary goal was avoiding a) the handler having
to know any of the details the api server abstracts (the version, the
content type, etc, how errors are written), b) making the http.Handler
terminal (no subsequent logic)

On Mon, Oct 12, 2015 at 5:07 PM, Daniel Smith notifications@github.com
wrote:

> In pkg/api/rest/rest.go
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/15442#discussion_r41801366
> :
> 
> >  }
> > 
> >  // Connecter is a storage object that responds to a connection request
> >  type Connecter interface {
> > -   // Connect returns a ConnectHandler that will handle the request/response for a request
> > -   Connect(ctx api.Context, id string, options runtime.Object) (ConnectHandler, error)
> > -   // Connect returns an http.Handler that will handle the request/response for a given API invocation.
> > -   // The provided responder may be used for common API responses.
> > -   Connect(ctx api.Context, id string, options runtime.Object, r Responder) (http.Handler, error)
> 
> I guess specifically what I'm confused about is that the handler will get
> a resp.Body to write to, but it has no way to plumb that response.Body into
> the Responder-- I'm sure I just don't understand the desired flow of
> information, though.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/15442/files#r41801366.
I see-- the caller needs to have parameterized the responder. Wouldn't it be much clearer to just have Responder's methods take an http.Response? And possibly save every caller the work.

Hrm. That opens the possibility that the http.Handler would mutate the
ResponseWriter with a wrapper.  Do we want to enable that?

> possibly save every caller the work.

I have visions of someone wrapping response writer with a special response
wrapper so they can manipulate the content-type or something.  We can
always refactor later.
